p: The first SARS outbreak began in the Guangdong Province, China, in late 2002 with 300 cases of atypical pneumonia [ 3, 4]. Despite the measures issued by the Chinese Government and the World Health Organization (WHO) to stop the transmission, SARS spread to “5 countries within 24 hours and to more than 30 countries on 6 continents within 6 months” ([ 5], p. 3), with over 8000 cases worldwide and a 10% fatality rate between 2002 and 2003 [ 6]. The primary source of infection was attributed to wild mammals traded in local markets for human consumption [ 5, 7]. The epidemic was brought under control by a remarkable coordinated response [ 4], albeit impacting significantly 36 countries socially, politically, and economically [ 8].
